content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle - easy to get slightly wrong the first try, and easy to see what went wrong for debugging.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a really interesting challenge.
That being said, I wonder if this would be viable in shortest mode.

H @Machiavelli_5040 and thanks for your Contribution !
-> I have to say that it was still too confus to me after first reading ...
-> but after second reading today AND analyzing your Test cases, i finally understand your Output expected sequence.
=> I've upvoted for you ...

BUT : i suggest you to explain more "friendly" each part of your expected sequence :
-> "(2⁰ = 1 times) the odd numbers in increasing order" means starting from 3 ?
-> "then 2¹ times the odd numbers in increasing order" means adding from 3*2 ?
-> "then 2² times the odd numbers in increasing order" means adding from 3*3 ?
-> "etc..." means repeat while < N ?
-> "and finally the powers of 2 in decreasing order" means adding down to 1 from the highest power of 2 < N ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original yet simple
No Fibonacci suite nor Cesar encoding has been hurt while designing this CoC
I'm wondering if the output should be N lines with 1 integer each instead, so that the players know where they failed and how

You may try to delete all the solution code and just print something (e.g. "3 5 7 9 10 13 6" for the current stub generator and a made-up answer with line breaks in between after you have temporarily changed the stub generator) to test which output format works better.
After having played some CoC games, I don't remember having to code the Fibonacci sequence... but now I know my Cesar encoding by heart!

Hi! Thank you for your feedback.
After re-reading the explanation, I do agree that it can be confusing (1 not being included in the odd numbers, etc...). I have rewritten the statement to include a more detailed presentation of the ordering and a step-by-step guide on how to get the result shown in the example.
Please feel free to tell me if something is still unclear or if something is too detailed!
Hi! Thanks for your feedback. I think you're right! I've added shortest mode.

I've now spent more than 15 minutes (the length of a Clash) rereading the Statement, and I'm still not sure I get it. 

It may be a good Puzzle, but it shouldn't be a Clash.
Hi! Thank you for your feedback. Maybe it became too lengthy, I replaced it with a quick description with a more detailed explanation of the example.
It's because some good souls swing their axe when they see one

Thanks for your feedback, I tried it, and it seems that no matter the output shape, having a lot of stuff to print is not great for debugging.
I think the players will have to use the first test cases to check why their code fails (if it fails) with the smaller outputs, and for that the current output shape seems clearer to me.
Thus, this should be the final version of the clash.
